Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Modeling and Industrial Applied Mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The REU program at North Carolina State University aims to get more undergraduates interested in pursuing academic and nonacademic careers in mathematics. The program does this by giving the students the opportunity to work on applied research problems in a supportive, collaborative environment that is part of a vibrant research department with strong collaboration with industry and government laboratories. The program combines a strong commitment to outreach, well thought-out programs for students, and a long-standing dedication to diversity in the mathematics work force. The interdisciplinary nature of the REU program attracts students who do not necessarily think of themselves as primarily interested in mathematics (some are double majors, or have math minors). Through this summer experience students learn the power of mathematical models, potentially interesting them in careers in the mathematical sciences.

In this REU program students are exposed to challenging and exciting real-world problems arising in industrial and government laboratory research. This experience benefits its participants in ways not possible with traditional coursework. Students learn valuable techniques of applied mathematics and learn how to work in teams to accomplish common objectives. The complexity and open-endedness of the problems provides a challenge that makes learning new techniques worthwhile. The fact that there may be no ready-made structures or body of results to cover the final problem formulation only compounds the excitement. REU students see the value placed on their work by those outside the University, in the "real world" of business and industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This REU program aims to provide a dynamic supportive environment to entice more undergraduates to pursue academic and nonacademic careers in mathematics. We accomplish this by recruiting and engaging students from underrepresented groups as well as students from colleges and universities with limited opportunities for research. During this award, we have had great success attracting women to our REU program (50% of all participants) and 25% of our REU participants are from the underrepresented groups including African­-Americans and Hispanics. In addition, more than half  of our REU students came from institutions with limited research opportunities in STEM or from small programs where students do not have exposure to the wide array of areas of mathematics. In effort to increase the number of students that pursue a STEM degree, we also provided the students with opportunities to work on applied research problems in a supportive, collaborative environment which is part of a vibrant research department with strong links to industry and government laboratories. This opportunity allows students to see career options beyond academia and to work with mentors from both academia and industry or laboratory settings, which include Laboratory for Analytic Sciences (NC State University), The Aerospace Corporation, and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 

The research from the REU program has resulted in 3 peer-reviewed publicaitons (one journal, one book chapter, and a proceedings paper). In addition, all REU groups present posters and give talks, many at national conferences and regional meetings.

Through participation in the REU program, the students gain practice communicating about mathematics as each student is required to give frequent progress reports, both oral and written, and to write a final paper and make a poster presentation and develop their abilities to work independently and collaboratively. In addition, by working closely with faculty, research scientists, graduate students and other undergraduate students, students feel that they are part of a bigger mathematical community and that they have important contributions to make, and can better visualize themselves as graduate students and later as faculty or research scientists.

A novel component of our program is the assignment of a graduate student assistant to each REU group. Graduate students provide an additional perspective and resource for their work. Having graduate students work with the undergraduates in this research context also helped the undergraduates visualize themselves as graduate students (this is especially important to students from small colleges). The interaction also benefits graduate students as it is a professional development opportunity through which they gain a variety of valuable skills. Many of our graduate students aspire to become faculty at small colleges or universities. Through this involvement of graduate students in REU projects we aim to train them to involve undergraduates in research experiences when they graduate and become faculty at small colleges/universities.
